I.  THE ENSUING PROJECT 
 
1.  To realize the goal of accelerated infrastructure development, the Government of the 
Philippines (the Government) requested urgent assistance from the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) to supplement capacity and improve systems and procedures for project development and 
project monitoring. In response, ADB is working with the Government on a proposed Infrastructure 
Preparation and Innovation Facility Project (the proposed project), which will support two key 
agencies responsible for national public infrastructure, the Department of Public Works and 
Highways (DPWH) and the Department of Transportation (DOTr). The project will assist the 
Government in making objective investment decisions, provide a robust project pipeline ready for 
implementation, and assist with the preparation activities to fill the infrastructure gap of the 
country.1 This paper outlines a technical assistance (TA) grant, proposed to help develop the 
capacity of the two agencies to implement the ensuring Project. It is categorized as a transaction 
TA grant. 
 
2.  The proposed project is included in the Country Operations and Business Plan 2017–
2019.2 The impact will be infrastructure development accelerated.3 It has the following outcome: 
delivery and quality of public infrastructure projects improved. The project comprises four outputs: 
(i) road and bridge projects prepared; (ii) water projects prepared; (iii) rail, public transport, port, 
and airport project prepared; and (iv) a project monitoring system prepared.  
 
3.  A TA loan is proposed as the financing modality for the proposed project. It is estimated 
to cost $114.06 million; of which $100 million will be financed by ADB’s ordinary capital resources. 
The Government will finance $14.06 million for taxes and duties and financial charges during 
implementation.4 The major expenditure items, approximately 93% of the total cost (including 
taxes and duties), are for consulting services to support the government project preparation and 
implementation activities for public sector investments.5 
 
4.  The TA loan fact-finding mission was held during 24 February–14 March 2017. The 
Government concurred with the impact, outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, and 
cost financing arrangements. The cost estimates and financing plan are provided in Appendix 1. 
 
5.   Besides  enhancing  planning  and  implementation  capacities  in  the  agencies,  the 
transaction TA grant will also support the development and establishment of the infrastructure 
project monitoring and management system in the National Economic and Development Authority 
(NEDA), Department of Finance (DOF), DOTr, and DPWH. 
 
6.  The transaction TA grant will be split into two phases; phase 1 will ensure smooth and 
timely start-up of the proposed project and phase 2 will implement a project management and 
monitoring system. The TA grant will directly support the Government and the proposed project 
by: (i) screening and prioritizing projects for inclusion in the proposed project; (ii) enhancing the 
current management and monitoring system and structures, (iii) identifying key specialist support 
to augment capacity in DOF, NEDA, DPWH, and DOTr (to be completed under phase 1), and (iv)

II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
7.  The TA will ensure the most effective support is derived from the proposed project by 
assisting DOTr and DPWH in project screening and prioritization. The selected projects will be 
the highest priority of the Government in terms of development needs and priorities, as well as 
specialist advice required. The identification as well as initial work on transformational projects 
such  as  large  bridges,  tunnels,  innovative  transport  solutions  and  flood  mitigation,  and 
management will require specialist support to augment capacity within DOTr and DPWH in the 
development of project management and monitoring system. 
 
8.  The TA will establish the implementation structure for the proposed project, to ensure 
readiness of DOTr and DPWH. The TA will also ensure that DOF, through DPWH and DOTr, is 
able to meet loan covenant reporting requirements for the proposed project. The TA will prepare 
and establish project management and monitoring systems and assist in the implementation of 
these systems within NEDA.   
 
9.  The TA will enable DOTr and DPWH to meet an urgent need for specialized assistance to 
push forward their ongoing sophisticated infrastructure projects. International experts can be 
sourced only in exceptional cases under existing national procurement systems.7 The specialized 
expertise provided by the TA will directly supplement skills and innovations urgently required by 
DOTr and DPWH to undertake pre-investment activities to be financed under the proposed project. 
 
10.  A series of consultation missions were conducted in March and April 2017 with DOF, 
NEDA, DOTr, and DPWH to discuss the requirements of the TA and how this relates and supports 
the  proposed  project  and  project  management  and  monitoring  systems.8 The  Government 
concurred with the outputs, activities, implementation arrangements, cost financing arrangements, 
and terms of references (TOR) for consultants.9 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities  
 
11.  Output  1:  Project  screening  and  prioritization.  The  TA  will  assist  NEDA  in  the 
screening of projects for inclusion in the proposed project in the context of the government’s 
overall infrastructure development program based on the Philippines Development Plan and 
Public Investment Program. This will ensure timely start-up of the proposed project and that 
maximum benefits are derived by selecting those projects that would benefit the Government 
most in terms of priority, complexity and requirement with respect to international expertise.

12.  Output 2: Development of management systems and structures. The TA will assess 
the current infrastructure program and project development systems and procedures within DOF, 
NEDA, DOTr and DPWH and assist the agencies to prepare project management and monitoring 
manuals  and  work  flow  charts  for  accelerated  project  preparation  and  approval,  using 
international best practices and experts in the areas of project management. Output 4 outlined 
below will establish the project management system and associated documentation. 
 
13.  Output 3: Specialist support to augment capacity in DOF, DOTr, and DPWH. The TA 
will augment capacity within DOF, DOTr, and DPWH and identify skill gaps in the executing and 
implementing agencies. The skill gap analysis will be used to determine needs for in-service 
training, and/or support from consultant specialists to enhance capacity and expedite project 
preparation and implementation activities.  
 
14.  Output 4: Implementation of the project management and monitoring system. The 
implementation of the project management and monitoring system prepared under output 2 will 
be delivered under this output. Output 4 will run for 4 years and assist the key oversight agencies, 
DOF and NEDA in project preparation and approval phases of the Government’s infrastructure 
programs. A team will be embedded within DOF and NEDA to implement the project management 
and monitoring system. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $5,500,000, of which $5,000,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-Others).10 The government will provide 
counterpart support in the form of staff, offices, permissions, logistical assistance, access to 
information and reports, and other in-kind contributions.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  DOF will be the executing agency, and NEDA, DPWH, and DOTr will be the implementing 
agencies. ADB will administer the TA through the Transport and Communications Division (SETC) 
of Southeast Asia Department. The expected TA effectivity date is 1 August 2017; the physical 
completion date is 28 February 2021. The TA financial closing date is 31 August 2021. 
 
17.  SETC will maintain regular contact with DOF, NEDA, DPWH, and DOTr, as well as with 
the consultants to ensure work proceeds according to the agreed schedules and expected outputs. 
TA review  missions  and  consultant  progress reports  will  provide  adequate monitoring  and 
evaluation of TA delivery. In addition to formal TA deliverables, consultants will be required to 
prepare brief quarterly reports every 3 months during the contract period. External peer review of 
consultant deliverables may be sought for soundness and objectivity.

18.  Consulting services. The TA will require 140 person months of international specialists 
and 332 person months of national specialists―for a total of 472 person months of specialist 
inputs. The consultants may provide support and advice in technical areas of project management, 
road and bridge engineering, flood protection works, tunneling, ports, airports, and railways. It will 
also provide support with the implementation of the project management and monitoring system. 
National specialists will be recruited to complement the international expertise and ensure 
adequate knowledge of local conditions and regulations. 
 
19.  In the first phase, for Outputs 1,2 and 3, the experts include: (i) project management 
specialists (5 person-months, individual, international), (ii) senior international experts (15 person-
months,  individual,  international),  and  (iii)  national  experts  (32  person-months,  individuals, 
national). The second phase, Output 4, will be prepared under Output 2 and the detailed TOR 
and recruitment of the firm to support the implementation of the project management and 
implantation  system.  Output-based  or  lump-sum  contracts may  be  considered  in  engaging 
consulting services to reduce administrative burden and improve economy, efficiency, and value 
for money. The team of consultants will work closely with DOF and NEDA staff to support and 
advise on an interim basis throughout the proposed project.  
 
20.  The consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time). The TA disbursement will be done following 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The 
detailed TOR for consultants for the first phase of the TA are included in the list of linked 
documents in Appendix 2. 
 
III.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of a technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $5,000,000 on a grant basis 
to the Government of the Philippines for Strengthening Infrastructure Capacity and Innovation for 
Inclusive Growth, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
